author: Robyn Ironside National Travel Writer
title: Tourism Australia and Austrade launch indigenous tourism campaign
text:
A FILM designed to reinvent the image of indigenous tourism in Australia has premiered in Sydney today after more than a year in the making.
Funded by Tourism Australia and Austrade , Our Country Is Waiting For You aims to change the perception that indigenous tourism experiences are dry, hot and dusty and limited to certain places. Appealing ... Behind the scenes at the filming of Tourism Australia's indigenous campaign Our Country is waiting for you by Brendan Fletcher and Warwick Thornton. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied
The three-minute clip showcases a range of beachfront and rainforest locations around the country, along with the Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney and Uluru.
Acclaimed film makers Brendan Fletcher and Warwick Thornton were commissioned to make the movie after years of consecutive declines in the number of overseas visitors seeking indigenous experiences.
In the last year, a mere 14 per cent of international tourists participated in an Aboriginal cultural experience.
“This is a story that needed to be told,” said Tourism Australia Managing Director John O’Sullivan. Different ... bush tucker experiences are a big drawcard for indigenous Tourism. Picture: Supplied. Source: Supplied
Margaret Campbell from tourism company Dreamtime Southern X said she hoped the short film would help people understand the diversity of Aboriginal experiences in Australia.
To be shown on international flights, at airports and in hotels, the film is expected to be seen by more than 50 million people in key markets including China, Malaysia, Indonesia, Korea and the US.
Mr Thornton said he hoped his “grandmother would cry” when she saw the film and the stunning images of indigenous people sharing their culture with American and Asian tourists.
“She will see special things happening with Aboriginal people around Australia,” said Mr Thornton, who directed the award-winning Samson and Delilah in 2009.
Mr Fletcher said every part of Australia was Aboriginal country.
“And every part of the country has a series of stories and experiences that are absolutely unique to that place,” he said.
